prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
Aita for giving a woman a taste of her own behavior
I'm sitting at the airport and this older lady sat down right next to me and took her iPad out and starts watching a show quite loud. 

To me this is a foul in public however I just ignored it and put my earbuds in. 

After a while I made a phone call using my earbuds. Literally 30 seconds into my call she interrupts me and asks me to quit being rude and talk quietly so she can hear her show.

I was as polite as I could and said that not only herself but everyone for about 10 feet and I could hear her show word for word and that making a phone call isn't rude but watching a show on your device full volume in a public waiting area is actually very rude and that is why people use headphones. 

She said she has every right to enjoy her show without being interrupted by a rude and selfish phone call or having to use headphones. 

I said she was absolutely right and I am completely wrong, please enjoy your show while we  wait for the plane and I will do  the same.       I then proceeded to take out my iPad and open ice cubes good cop bad cop music video and play it full volume on my device without my earbuds. 

I have never seen someone storm off so mad. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. So, the scenario is that an older lady is watching a show on her iPad at the airport with loud volume. The author initially ignores it, puts on earbuds, and then makes a phone call. The lady interrupts him and asks him to be quiet so she can hear her show. The author responds by pointing out that her loud volume is actually rude and that people use headphones. Then, in a sarcastic way, he says she's right and proceeds to play a music video on his iPad at full volume, causing her to storm off.

First, I need to analyze the actions of both parties. The lady is using her device loudly in a public space, which is generally considered rude. The author, instead of escalating the situation, first tries to be polite and points out the issue. But when the lady persists, he retaliates by playing his own media loudly. 

The key here is whether the author's response was an appropriate way to handle the situation. While the lady was indeed in the wrong for using loud volume without headphones, the author's retaliation could be seen as equally rude. Instead of just confronting her politely and maybe asking her to lower the volume, he took it further by playing loud media, which escalated the conflict. Even though he was defending his right to make a phone call, his response might not be the best approach. 

Public settings usually expect people to respect others' space and noise levels. While the lady was wrong, the author's response could be seen as a provocation. The question is whether he overstepped by playing loud media. Even if he was justified in his initial complaint, the way he handled it might have been excessive. 

So, the answer would depend on whether the author's actions were a reasonable response. Since he took it to a level of retaliation rather than just standing his ground, he might be in the wrong. Therefore, the answer would be A (Yes).
